The **economy ofSan Marino** is a developed free-market economy focused on
industries such as tourism, banking, and the manufacture of ceramics,
clothing, fabrics, furniture, paints, spirits, tiles, and wine. Taken
together, the manufacturing and financial sector make up more than half of the
national GDP. The primary sector contribution to the GDP of the country is
marginal, with the main agricultural products being wine and cheeses. In
addition, San Marino sells collectible postage stamps to philatelists.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of San Marino is characterized as a developed free-market economy with a focus on several key industries including tourism, banking, and manufacturing.
• The manufacturing sector in San Marino produces a variety of goods such as ceramics, clothing, fabrics, furniture, paints, spirits, tiles, and wine.
• Combined, the manufacturing and financial sectors account for more than half of San Marino’s national Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• The primary sector, which includes agriculture, contributes only marginally to the overall GDP of San Marino.
• The main agricultural products of San Marino are wine and cheeses, reflecting the limited but specialized nature of its primary sector.
• Additionally, San Marino generates revenue by selling collectible postage stamps to philatelists, indicating a niche market within its economy.

text:
San Marino's per-capita GDP stands at almost $53,000 in 2023, placing the
country 17th in the world. Overall, the per capita level of output and
standard of living is comparable to the richest regions of Italy. Most of the
food, water, and other raw resources are imported from Italy, including also
the totality of electricity and natural gas. Taxes, especially on labor and
capital income, are generally much lower than in Italy, therefore, there are
extremely strict requirements to obtain citizenship.

Following the global recession of 2007–2008, San Marino's economy contracted
considerably, especially in the finance and banking sector. As a result, GDP
decreased by 40% between 2008 and 2019, and unemployment, which was
practically nonexistent until 2007, arose to around 5–8 % in the years
following the great recession. During the same period, banks' deposits
plummeted, going from almost 14 billion euros in 2008 to 5.2 billion. An
important liquidity crisis followed suit, also made worse by the absence of a
lender of last resort, as San Marino is not part of the European Union. As a
consequence of these events, several banks have been bailed-out by the
government, including Cassa di Risparmio, the main bank of the country. Still,
the banking system remains weak, with balance sheets that are impaired by Non-
Performing Loans, which amount to 114% of the country's GDP.

The country is shifting away from an economic model typical of tax havens,
reliant on banks and tax secrecy. Major steps in this direction were taken in
2010 with the abolition of anonymous companies and in 2017 with the abolition
of banking secrecy. Currently, San Marino actively cooperates with
international organizations, especially the Council of Europe and the European
Union, for what regards fighting against money laundering and terrorism
financing. As a result, San Marino was removed from the Italian blacklist of
tax havens in 2014, and from that of Ecofin in 2017.
openai_summarised_points: • In 2023, San Marino's per-capita GDP is nearly $53,000, ranking the country 17th globally in terms of per capita income.
• The standard of living and per capita output in San Marino are comparable to the wealthiest regions of Italy.
• The country imports most of its food, water, and raw materials from Italy, including 100% of its electricity and natural gas supplies.
• Taxation on labor and capital income in San Marino is significantly lower than in Italy, which is accompanied by very stringent citizenship acquisition requirements.
• The global recession of 2007–2008 caused a substantial contraction in San Marino’s economy, particularly affecting the finance and banking sectors.
• Between 2008 and 2019, San Marino’s GDP declined by 40%, reflecting the prolonged economic downturn.
• Unemployment, which was nearly nonexistent before 2007, rose to approximately 5–8% in the years following the global recession.
• Bank deposits in San Marino fell sharply from nearly 14 billion euros in 2008 to 5.2 billion euros in subsequent years.
• The country experienced a severe liquidity crisis exacerbated by the lack of a lender of last resort, as San Marino is not a member of the European Union.
• The government intervened with bailouts for several banks, including Cassa di Risparmio, the country’s principal banking institution.
• Despite government support, the banking sector remains fragile, with Non-Performing Loans (NPLs) totaling 114% of San Marino’s GDP, indicating significant financial distress.
• San Marino is transitioning away from an economic model characteristic of tax havens, which previously relied heavily on banking secrecy and tax advantages.
• Key reforms include the abolition of anonymous companies in 2010 and the elimination of banking secrecy in 2017.
• The country actively collaborates with international bodies such as the Council of Europe and the European Union to combat money laundering and terrorism financing.
• Due to these reforms and cooperation efforts, San Marino was removed from the Italian blacklist of tax havens in 2014.
• Subsequently, San Marino was also removed from the Ecofin blacklist of tax havens in 2017.

text:
In the years preceding the great recession, San Marino's public finances were
in very good shape, with a central government budget surplus and no national
debt. During the global downturn, the government adopted measures to dampen
the shock on the real economy and to bail out financial institutions, which
came at a high price for the soundness of public finances. The official
estimates place government debt at 32% of GDP in 2020, however, the actual
value is equal to 86% according to the International Monetary Fund, which
takes a broader view in considering government's liabilities.

While San Marino does not issue public debt securities that are traded on
financial markets, its creditworthiness is monitored by the rating agency
Fitch. The current rating of BB+ is the result of several downgrades that
occurred during and after the great recession: from AA to A in 2009 and to BBB
in 2016.
openai_summarised_points: • Prior to the global financial crisis known as the great recession, San Marino maintained very strong public finances characterized by a central government budget surplus and the absence of any national debt.

• In response to the economic downturn caused by the global recession, the San Marino government implemented various measures aimed at mitigating the impact on the real economy and providing financial support to banking institutions, which significantly compromised the robustness of public finances.

• Official government estimates reported San Marino's public debt at 32% of GDP in the year 2020; however, the International Monetary Fund (IMF), employing a more comprehensive assessment of government liabilities, estimated the actual debt level to be substantially higher at 86% of GDP.
• San Marino does not issue publicly traded debt securities on financial markets, distinguishing its public finance structure from many other nations.
• The creditworthiness of San Marino is evaluated by the international rating agency Fitch Ratings, which has progressively downgraded the country's credit rating over time.

• Fitch Ratings assigned San Marino a current credit rating of BB+, reflecting a series of downgrades that began during the great recession, including a drop from AA to A in 2009 and a further downgrade to BBB in 2016.

In the years following the Italian unification of 1861, several treaties were
signed between San Marino and the newborn Kingdom of Italy. The first such
treaty addressing economic issues was signed in 1865 for the introduction of
the Sammarinese lira, which was equivalent to the Italian lira and fully
recognized as a legal tender in both countries. Probably the most important
agreement is the convention of friendship and good neighborhood that was
signed in 1939, during fascism. This treaty establishes a customs union with
Italy and sets out some limitations on the carrying out of certain economic
activities, like tobacco cultivation, gambling, and radio broadcasting.

While San Marino is not part of the European Union, it had a customs union
with it since 1991, and there is an open border between the two areas. San
Marino also uses the Euro as its currency since 2000, when an agreement was
signed with Italy, on behalf of the EU. A new monetary convention was signed
in 2012 directly with the EU, covering a wider range of financial and monetary
issues. San Marino is also allowed to mint Sammarinese Euro coins, which are
printed by the Italian mint in Rome but feature a different national design
than Italian Euro coins. Since they are minted in a very limited amount, they
are rare and highly appreciated by coin collectors.

The main commercial partner of San Marino is Italy, with which around 88% of
exports and 78% of imports take place (2017). Other important partners are the
other countries of the EU, especially France and Germany.
openai_summarised_points: • Following the Italian unification of 1861, San Marino and the Kingdom of Italy signed several treaties addressing economic relations between the two states.

• In 1865, the first treaty concerning economic issues was signed, introducing the Sammarinese lira, which was equivalent in value to the Italian lira and recognized as legal tender in both San Marino and Italy.
• The most significant agreement in their economic relationship is the 1939 convention of friendship and good neighborhood, signed during the fascist period in Italy.

• The 1939 treaty established a customs union between San Marino and Italy and imposed certain restrictions on specific economic activities within San Marino, including tobacco cultivation, gambling, and radio broadcasting.
• Although San Marino is not a member of the European Union, it has maintained a customs union with the EU since 1991, facilitating an open border between San Marino and EU territories.
• Since 2000, San Marino has used the Euro as its official currency, following an agreement signed with Italy acting on behalf of the European Union.
• In 2012, San Marino signed a new monetary convention directly with the EU, expanding the scope of financial and monetary cooperation beyond the previous agreements.
• Under these agreements, San Marino is authorized to mint its own Euro coins, which are produced by the Italian mint in Rome but feature unique national designs distinct from Italian Euro coins.
• Sammarinese Euro coins are minted in limited quantities, making them rare and highly valued by numismatists and coin collectors worldwide.
• Italy remains San Marino’s principal commercial partner, accounting for approximately 88% of San Marino’s exports and 78% of its imports as of 2017.
• Other significant trading partners for San Marino include other European Union countries, particularly France and Germany.

In 2022, the sector with the highest number of companies registered in San
Marino is Retail Trade with 756 companies followed by Wholesale Trade and
Services with 753 and 752 companies respectively.
openai_summarised_points: • In 2022, the sector with the highest number of companies registered in San Marino was Retail Trade, comprising 756 companies.
• The Wholesale Trade sector was the second largest in terms of company registrations in San Marino in 2022, with a total of 753 companies.
• The Services sector ranked third in the number of registered companies in San Marino in 2022, with 752 companies.

text:
One of the sources of income from tourism comes from the sale of historic
coins and stamps. In 1894, San Marino issued the first commemorative stamps
and since then that has been part of a large livelihood in the republic. All
10 of the Post Offices of San Marino sell these stamps and collectible coins,
including "Legal Gold Tender Coins".

Traditional economic activities in San Marino were food crops, sheep farming,
and stone quarrying. Today farming activities focus on grain, vines, and
orchards, as well as animal husbandry (cattle and swine).
openai_summarised_points: • One significant source of income from tourism in San Marino derives from the sale of historic coins and stamps.
• San Marino issued its first commemorative stamps in 1894, marking the beginning of a substantial and ongoing economic activity centered on philately and numismatics within the republic.
• All 10 Post Offices in San Marino participate in the sale of these commemorative stamps and collectible coins, which include "Legal Gold Tender Coins," contributing to the local economy.
• Historically, San Marino’s traditional economic activities comprised food crop cultivation, sheep farming, and stone quarrying.
• In contemporary times, agricultural practices in San Marino have shifted focus toward the production of grain, cultivation of vines and orchards, and animal husbandry involving cattle and swine.
